REVIEW_TITLE: A great place for family bonding
REVIEW_BODY: A place with history and a place to relax with family. We love the greenery, the sea, the history (with board information), the playground... and we saw a number of wild roosters, including green viper.

If you want to have a taste of a peaceful nature reserve in a highly urbanised city, and you only have a couple of hours, this may be it.
You can reach there easily by public transport (subway, buses...). A walk of no more than 10 min from the main road would take you to the reserve.It is generally v peaceful (unlike many other larger reserves near the reservoirs) and you would have a good reflection while walking through the woods. Near the entrance is a restaurant for SE Asian food (Tamarind Hill) - highly recommended. Coming out of the woods on the other side is the sea, and you can then stroll down along the seaside to have a good look at the Singapore south.

Started out as a good natural ramble from the Labrador mrt as you go up a slightly steep gradient past the Villa Samadhi with plenty of vegetation at the side. The historical significance emerges as you pass the cannon and figurines of soldiers with their artillery as it was in the defence of the island against theJapanese in the Pacific War. There's even a tunnel where artillery was stored..
Further up it's the waterfront where you can see boats, container ships and the cable cars above. Unfortunately there are picnic grounds with barbecue pots resembling East Coast Park which mar the natural surroundings. Hopefully the groups which make use of them clear their refuse as we could see large numbers of plastic wrappers, bottles etc floating in the sea at the breakwater near where people were fishing (thought this wasn't allowed?)
The boardwalk was good, passing a green mangrove pool, very picturesque, and delightfully, we saw a monitor lizard in the leaf litter, four monkeys on the rail of the boardwalk and a family of hens and chickens, a couple of squirrels.
You can exit at the other gate of the Labrador mrt station and walk across to the PSA building for lunch..
It's a one hour walk in the park, not counting time spent on the Mrt and walking to the PSA building. Not as challenging and interesting as the Southern Ridges as it's a shorter walk, less steep but noisier with visitors and their food and hilarity.

One of the few battlefronts to face off with the advancing Japanese troops during the war, only a few artefacts remain to remind of the grim history. A series of steep walk to the to top of the park where the defending troops were entrenched to keep a watch over the sea horizon. Shady trees provide much welcome relief and time out from the city life.
You can wander onto the boardwalks over the shorelines, Berlayer Creek Mangrove trail for the wildlife there and the Bukit Chermin Boardwalk that overlook the Keppel Marina. Windy and shady to spend an afternoon

Interesting part to know about ww2 history in sg. There are many greenery and historic traces of ww2 to discover here. It doesn’t feel hot as the trees provide plenty of shades. Great place to do a learning journey or simply a nice stroll or Cycling. Nice sea view nearby great for family outing.

Came back to Labrador Park with the kids during December. A few small play areas to keep them entertained and good views out over the nearby ships. Being the monsoon season the grass was a little wet for running around on (and quite muddy too). A few mosquitoes around so best to use spray.

REVIEW_TITLE: Labrador's amenities eclipse other bigger park in Singapore.
REVIEW_BODY:
LABRADOR NATURE RESERVE. LABRADOR PARK.
Singapore.
“Built on the edge of the secondary forest with a prime vantage point of the cliff-side vegetation and a picturesque view of the sea, Labrador Nature Reserve is an oasis of tranquility and natural wonders. Thriving with wildlife, the park is a favorite haunt of nature lovers.”
That was the Singapore Parks Authorities’ somewhat exaggerated version of what Labrador Park is today. Vegetation has covered all of the escarpment and the density prevents any reasonable view of the park and the beach below. As for the ‘thriving wildlife’ no animals bigger than a squirrel can be seen except a resident peacock and some jungle fowls loitering around near the creek area.
The Labrador Park I knew when I was young was a rocky beach at the foot of cliffs, that was some parts cover with coarse vegetation and some parts bare, with a narrow rocky path. We would navigate the path down to the beach to swim. It was crowded during the weekends, only with locals, mainly youths. Reclamation had erased what little beach there was and you can’t swim there anymore.
Today Labrador has been transformed into a busy recreation ground where tourists came to view the war remains of British War embankments and a sixteen inch gun and to learn of the history on how the guns were facing the wrong direction when the Japanese invaders came during the WW2. A guide would take the tourist down the to the sea side where one end of the esplanade is long jetty with a history of it being used by a Japanese Oil Refinery to convey its products to small tankers. At the other end the tourist would come across a pill box preserved as a reminder of a beach machine gun defense post standing next to an obelisk. No sign of explanation of what the object was doing there, can be found. As the tourists venture further they would come across a strange looking rock that has a history of a meeting point for pirates coming to shore. Though it doesn’t has any resemblance to a dragon it has an imaginary name ‘Dragon’s Teeth Gate’. There used to be a small cave somewhere along the cliff, but there is none to be seen.
The mouth of the creek is where the people usually end their walks, however there is an extension by way of a board walk. Berlayer creek used to be a muddy clogged up stream. It is now a beautiful rivulet that is pleasant to walk along to the MRT station at the main road. Bukit Chermin Boardwalk is best for evening and morning walks when the sun is not so strong. Great sunset can be seen along the boardwalk as you stroll along the mangrove, and one can gaze at the ferries coming into port from Batam. At the farthest point out to sea the Red Beacon stands, to warn ships from the rocky shore.
Labrador is not a large park by Singapore standards but its amenities far out shines other bigger parks. One plus factor are the clean washrooms which are well placed throughout. There is a campsite, BBQ pits, Children’s playground, exercise areas, drinks fountains, drinks machines, benches (are everywhere) and designated areas where the angler can pitch his rod.
In my younger days, buses were infrequent and we used to walk uphill to Labrador Villa Road then down a cliff path to the beach. Now there is a Labrador Station MRT with many buses stopping alongside, and all you need is a pleasant walk along the Berlayer Creek. Cars go right up to the park using Port Road which runs alongside Berlayer Creek and Labrador Villa Road. At the end of Labrador Villa Road a holiday hostel for nurses, used to stand. Now in its place is a restored 1920 colonial garrison that has been taken over by Villa Samadhi Hotel with its popular in-house restaurant Tamarind Hill. After a hot day in the sun at the park it is refreshing to chill out and have tea at Tamarind Hill Restaurant.
Love this place... Usually comes here for walk in the evening.. very cool and nice to see all the yacht parked nearby...

REVIEW_TITLE: From carpark C to Bukei Chermin boardwalk
REVIEW_BODY: Arrived just as the sun was beginning to appear, on a cool Saturday morning. The drive in to the most distant car park (C) is spookily quiet, but once at C, there was lighting and a well constructed footpath. At the starting point, the lights of the Pasir Panjang port shimmer across the water, and the continuous rumble of machinery reminds you that you are still in the city. The path took us around the Dragon's Teeth gate, and meandered along the coastline to the Bukit Chermin boardwalk. There is a branch along the Berlayer Creek walk which leads to the Labrador Park MRT, but we didn't take this. There are some tranquil views along the way of Keppel Island and Sentosa Island, but you are constantly aware that you are still in the heart of one of the most densely populated cities in the world. Turning westward from the carpark, you stroll along a parklike stretch of greenery, complete with roosters, hens and a solitary peacock. Access to the gun batteries is from Car park A; we didn't have time for that this time, but will return to explore that side of the park. Toilets and rest shelters available.

REVIEW_TITLE: Interesting Indiana Jones type corner of Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: We looped around the park along the boardwalks, around the coast and then into the jungle. Each section of the walk was interesting, we saw radio-controlled planes...kingfishers and lizards on the boardwalk section...lovely giggling groups enjoying the Sunday afternoon in the park... fishermen reeling in off lines...the impressive container port and tankers...and then into the nature reserve to explore the old battlements - which had a sense of Indiana Jones to them. Cracking little walk, 3.5km in all. The noise from the insects in the nature reserve was incredible, almost worth the trek alone.

Returned to Labrador Nature Reserve with the kids today. A little later than I would have liked, so it was quite hot by the time we arrived. There are 2 small playgrounds for children, and not too busy. A few open spaces for kicking a ball around. The walk out on the jetty is interesting.

For someone to have fun with family and friends at the same time not crowded madly or commercialised like East Coast Park. This is the place to walk around, play around, and sit quietly and enjoy the nature.

If you love the sound of water and visits to the seaside, you will love Labrador Nature Reserve. Located near Keppel Bay, you can see the busy ships coming into Singapore's port. There is also a small and old harbour where you can walk out to, to enjoy the cool sea breeze.

REVIEW_TITLE: Ingapore A pleasant 45 minute Riverside Walk-Labrador Park
REVIEW_BODY: Travel to Labrador MRT station on the Circle Line. At Labrador station. Turn Right out of the station and and follow the path to the right. The walk takes about 35-45 minutes along the river and past the Yacht Marina. When you reach the end of the path, (In the future the path will continue to Harbour Front Cruise Centre) turn left and walk down the side of multi storey apartments. At the main road turn right and walk about ¼ mile to Harbour Front.

REVIEW_TITLE: A nature reserve with World War II legacy
REVIEW_BODY: It was an artillery garrison during World War II built by the British Army against Japanese invasion but it turned out to be an ineffective defense. As the big guns were installed on hills, the entire installation has been converted into a nature park. The view is nice when visitors look out to the sea. With breezes ruffling the leaves, the whole historic site feels like come back to live ...
Singapore does not stop to amaze you . Great view of the sea and nice breeze and sunset . Easily accessible by MRT .

Went to Labrador for office family day. Nice place with fantastic view of the clear blue sea. There's playground and few monuments around the place. There's lots of tree and sheltered area. Ample parking space. Near the mrt as well (within walking distance). Good for exercising and breathing fresh air.

It's a nature park not to be missed if you are a history lover. There are quite a few sites to see eg the Dragon tooth gate and 6-inch gun.

Do be prepared to walk a bit though and bring along your insect repellent.

Nearest MRT station to here is Labrador Park and if you are driving, go to car park B or C to walk along the coast (leisure family walks)

This park is conveniently situated cĺose to the sea. Vegetation is nice and wild. You can scouts and monkeys. After a nice track you can choose to have your own food or going to the restaurant nearby. Don't forget water, mosquito repellent and sun cream.

REVIEW_TITLE: Half a day for the Labrador nature park.
REVIEW_BODY:
Built on the edge of the secondary forest with a prime vantage point of the cliff-side vegetation and a picturesque view of the sea, Labrador Nature Reserve is an oasis of tranquillity and natural wonders. Thriving with wildlife, the park is a favourite haunt of nature lovers. I could hear songs from a variety of bird species, including those of the Oriental Magpie-robin and Black-naped Oriole. Took a leisurely stroll through the Berlayer creek mangrove trail and reached the coastal cliff.

The Berlayer Creek mangrove trail is 960m long and is one of the few remaining mangrove areas in the city area which is home to back mangrove species, as well as a myriad of fauna and flora, including one of the highest densities of molluscs in Singapore.

The coastal area is the most developed part of Labrador Park and this paved pedestrian path runs along the water. This is where I saw a few visitors can be found make in the children’s playground, scenic jogging trails and barbecue pits. There’s also an elevated boardwalk over the water where I spotted mudskippers, sea grasses and small crabs.
If the Berlayer Creek was all about mangroves, then the 330m Bukit Chermin Boardwalk was where we got close to the sea.

Behind the developed coastal area is the jungle. This is where Labrador Park feels a world away from urban Singapore. The trees covered with vines were so dense they practically blocked out the sun . The limited network of trails were paved and had stairs and hand railings where necessary, making Labrador Park one of Singapore’s easiest nature reserves for walking. The park is home to more than 70 species of birds including wild parrots and bright yellow orioles.

Amid the jungle I saw some moss-covered remains from World War II including bunkers and gun batteries. The area that is now Labrador Nature Reserve was once Fort Pasir Panjang, one of the military forts built by the British to protect the port of Singapore. Informational signs dispel common myths like that Singapore lost to the Japanese invaders because the guns at these coastal forts were pointed facing the wrong direction (in fact, they could rotate 360-degrees but were not placed for firing inland and had the wrong kind of ammo).

Combining forest trails rich in birdlife and a beachfront park, Labrador Park is scattered with evocative British war relics, only rediscovered in the 1980s. The reserve’s hilly terrain sweeps down to the shore, where expansive lawn, shade and the sound of lapping waves invited a lazy picnic.

Labrador Nature Reserve is part of the Southern Ridges, which also comprises Mount Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill Park, and Kent Ridge Park.
To Reach: Take the MRT to Labrador Park and you will find the entrance right next to the exit. There are no admission charges. Remember to take your water bottles, there are no water stations here.

Located close to the Alexandra Retail Centre (the ARC) and accessible by car, taxi and bus. This is a little piece of nature tucked away from the hustle and bustle. Visitors to the park will enjoy the peacefulness of its surroundings, water views (with the port on the opposite), and even a little bit of Singapore's history. An old fort used by the resistance force in defending the southern shore of Singapore against enemy attacks during the Second World War still stands close to the water. Barbeque pits are also available for bookings. There are two small playgrounds for children.

A nice place to take someone on a picnic date, a place for small gatherings amongst friends and a hang-out for families with little children.

REVIEW_TITLE: Good picnic spot and great morning walk!
REVIEW_BODY: Reached here early morning and what a sight we were greeted with...peacocks! Did a great boardwalk and then walked towards the tunnel after our breakfast picnic. unfortunately the tunnels are shut now

Used to be a fort, or part of a extensive defense network for singapore, one cannon still remains at its original position, but the view from these gun emplacements were obstructed by trees and vegetation over growth, at the foot of this hill, you will find the dragon tooth gate, i guess the whole place can be a jice quiet spot for family picnic.
Pretty quiet place, mostly untouched by modernization, a good place for nature lovers to go. If you can stay long enough, you can see the sky littered with stars.
Very pleasant, quiet park suitable for running. Many families with young children. The park is just across from Sentosa island.

REVIEW_TITLE: A tiny bit of rain forest feeling
REVIEW_BODY: The forest itself provides with a taste of rain forest feeling. It is hiwever very small area. On the boardwalk no facilities like kiosks etc. The sea view after the hectic city centre is relaxing - if you don’t mind those tens of tankers. Anyway, a giod spot to see the sunset.

My wife and I spent the morning here during our visit to Singapore. We took the boardwalk through the Mangroves out from the MRT and walked back along the coastal footpath. Lovely little reserve and very popular with walkers and joggers, though neither seemed to disturb the wildlife. During our visit there wasn’t a great deal to see though we did manage a flyover White-bellied Sea Eagle carrying a fish and 2 Eastern Cattle Egret. The boardwalk and footpaths are very well maintained. There are some facilities in the reserve a couple of toilet blocks and a cold drinks machine. We checked the Dragonfly pond on our return journey and managed a Sultan (Dragonfly), 2 others we were unable to identify. Recommended.

Labrador Nature Reserve is nice coastal park in the the location of the World War Two Singapore artillery defences! The park has a pier a one end, as well as playgrounds, public toilets and the remains of the historic defences! Worth a look if your in the area!
Boardwalk is a lovely walk along the inlet, with lots of birds and not too many people. Take a drink as once you get to the harbourside end it is a long walk to anywhere.

When I was a kid, frequent this park, fishing along the coast. Heard a lot of eerie stories about this place.

The park has not changed much and some of the war relics can still be seen here like the machine gun post box. I remember that there is some sort of a underground tunnel somewhere in the park.

REVIEW_TITLE: A long concrete road to the beach and poor gastronomy
REVIEW_BODY: Labrador Park is close to an MRT station but there is still a long way to the beach. The atmosphere in the park is very calm - even on a Sunday - and the landmarks are interesting. On our way back we arrived at the two Indian Restaurants in the relatively new MRT. Station of Labrador Park. One is vegetarian, the other one which we visited - Sankranthi & Paratha Nation - is not.After our visit to the Labrador Park where we missed the gastronomy, we were happy to find this restaurant in the station. It looks clean - but it has no atmosphere and resembles a student'ts canteen. The menu is to pay in advance and is served later - but it was delicious (Chicken Tikka). The prices are moderate (although the atmosphere is more like in a food court). Thus: very pragmatic and useful for the hungry.visitors of the Nature Reserve but no place for socialising.

We went there for a morning walk and were a bit disappointed. There is really not much to see or do. Not much shade along the boardwalk. We stayed for less than an hour. There are definitely lots of better places in Singapore to go for a nature walk.

REVIEW_TITLE: Nice coastal park, good for if you have a lot of time in Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: We thought this park was a must see visit and we only had a few days In Singapore. If you’re trying to do the city in 4-5 days, this park can be skipped. However if you have more time and enjoy walking, it is a nice place. The coastal view is pretty and they’ve laid out fun pirate facts throughout the park.

REVIEW_TITLE: Not sure what I would find.
REVIEW_BODY: I worked at the military port at Tanjong Berlayer 50 years ago which is now part of the nature reserve. I was a little surprised to find that there were still some parts that I recognised. It certainly brought back plenty of memories.

Labrador Park has a series of fortifications that were originally built in the 19th century that are now well preserved and demonstrate how Singapore was defended. The fortifications were added to over the following years, including up to WW2. For anyone interested in military and colonial history this is a park that is worth spending some time in. There are broadwalks along the shore leading back to Vivo City and the Labrador Park MRT station which are interesting as they showcase some of the local flora and fauna. The views of the western entrance to Keppel Harbour are nice. There is not much shade on the broadwalks (it can get hot!) so make sure you wear a hat and carry water, or do it either early morning or evening.

Rich variety of flora and fauna , picturesque view of sea and sunset, rocky sea cliff, indulgences include resort, spa, food and beverages. An oasis of tranquility and natural wonder. We trekked the nature trail and discovered serenity within. We also took a stroll past the imposing 6 inch guns, machine gun posts and through the historic 1886 built casemates. Our experienced tour guide brought us through the times of WWII. Do go also for the uniquely created spa therapies in colonial villas. Enjoy the delectable spa cuisine that pampers the health conscious individuals.

REVIEW_TITLE: Beautiful boardwalk along Singapore's southern coast
REVIEW_BODY:
For those who love to walk, this is one beautiful park they can enjoy in the south.
You can start the walk from the hill and then wind down to the park below alongside the shore. The jetty on the right side has been developed and opened recently so anglers now have more choice.
If you walk to the left and continue hugging the coast, you will soon reach the boardwalk section overhanging the sea. This will take you soon beside a very unique architecture, the Reflections condominium...and if you have the energy you could even cross the bridge after reaching the end of the marina to go to Keppel Island, where you could walk around the island. Here, there are a couple of eateries or cafés for those who like to have a pit stop before retracing their steps.

REVIEW_TITLE: Scenic sea view near the city
REVIEW_BODY:
One can take a nature walk up the hill or broad walk along the shore, for us we opted for the broad walk as we want to enjoy the sea breeze and the sunset view.
This is a favorite place to go for family, couples and friends to hang out in the weekend.
It was kind of crowded when we were there.
The view is lovely, one can get to see the new cargo port and Jurong Island at the West and on the East, one can see the Iconic condo Reflection, Keppel Bay and Harbour Front. And right at the front the Sentosa Island can view from afar.
Apart from this view, for the history buff, you can get to learn a bit more of the Singapore history here, such as viewing the replica of Dragon Teeth Gate, or Lot's Wife as called by some. (Original was blow up by the British in 1848 to widen the channel. Damn you, British!), the story of the British war with the Pirates (yes, there were pirates then) and the machine gun fort that still stood at site.
With the sea breeze and the sun setting over the horizon.
This is one lovely place to spend a nice weekend together with your love one.

A hidden gem in Singapore. Catch the MRT to this nature reserve. A peaceful walk through the rain forest with sea breezes on one side. War relics around the site. Worth the visit. Possibly go in the afternoon to escape the heat.

This really isn't anything special. Just a nature reserve with not much to see. I just can't give it a good review because it's not worth visiting. I'm always in support of a nature reserve. We took the MRT and a long walk to the park and it just wasn't exciting or interesting. I'll never go back here. But if you're a park lover, maybe it's worth seeing a new park.

A quiet location away from the centre of Singapore. The nature walk takes you up steps and through woodland. You can see the remains of an old fort and there is a large gun. We walked along the promenade and across a long broad walk. Worth a visit. We took a taxi to and from our hotel 7 dollars each way.

My husband and I walked from Viva. But in actual fact you can take the mrt from Viva to Labardor Park which is two stops away.

We walked up the Tamarind Hill which has a restaurant but also a lot of history. With story boards, viewing decks and the 6 inch gun.

You can also also the park from the hill. The park is beautiful. You have the option taking the boardwalk towards Kepple or heading back to the Mrt station. Beautiful day out.

A great place to observe wildlife a short distance from the city. Start from Labrador Park MRT and go via the river boardwalk through the Mangroves then along the seashore and return through the park. We saw an array of birds, squirrels, lizards small & large. From here you can see the only cliffs Singapore island has. There are frequent information boards.

Labrador is more like a large park with some WWII remnants. A great place to stroll by the sea and have a pick nick (there are even barbecue stations you can use). Nice pathway right by the water. You can take MTR to Labrador Park station and head straight to the sea. Then walk south east along the water all the way to Keppel Bay. Part of the pathway is over water which was nice. Either take the bus back or head to Harbour Front MTR. Relaxing!

REVIEW_TITLE: For a dose of green in the middle of the Singapore city
REVIEW_BODY: Labrador Nature Reserve and its accompanying park overlooking the sea is an easy 45 minute, 2.5km walk. Some parts are slightly uphill but not for more than 100m per stretch. The signages are highly informative and paint a good picture about the canons, the gun battery and its placement point on the old Fort. The park is a comfortable walk, has playgrounds, a bbq pit to rent and public toilets for convenience. The park also provides access to the Dragon's Tooth, a replica relic of Singapore's past.
Really enjoyed my 2 hours strolling here. The nature was breath-takingly beautiful and the history plaques an unexpected bonus. Plenty of shelters to rest in as well.

REVIEW_TITLE: Another coastal park with Sentosa and Reflections views
REVIEW_BODY: Closest MRT is CC27 „Labrador Park”. From there, walk south ca 300m to the park. Coastal forest with trails, nice viewpoints (harbour, Sentosa island, Reflections complex) and a reproduction of the “dragon teeth” rocks that once marked the harbour entry.

the sunrise and sunset..and also why sg is one world busiest port too from all the container ships in the distance lol

with the many more mrt stops every year, getting to parks is being more accessible...though it's still around 500m to 1km away from Labrador Park MRT. and this place have the history and also the class of the rich and famous as the boardwalk neighbor the many condos around that area too lol...(history can just read on the many other superb reviews here lol)

The entry to Labrador Reserve is free

The place is great for jogging, Photography and fishing.

Fishing: there is a jetty which is dedicated for fishing and you don’t need to be a member or pay anything to fish here. Totally legal and fun!

Photography: plenty of spots if you keep walking along the water. Can’t even describe the beauty, you just have to be here to see it for yourself.

Jog: Awesome track all along to run, jog or cycle. I usually take my hoverboard here. Less people and nice fresh air helps.

Tip: You get a great view of Keppel Bay residential apartments.

Super tip: there is a small uphill track with little bits and knowledge of singaporean history for tourists, near carpark C. Enjoy!!

REVIEW_TITLE: Easy walk and reflective gun spot!!
REVIEW_BODY:
This is a very gentle stroll.

From the Labrador Park MRT station walk alongside Berlayer Creek for about 1KM, a well maintained promenade type walk. Then the choice is turn left for an easy looking promenade walk or right towards the Labrador Nature Reserve.

There are a couple of highlights (e.g. Dragon’s Teeth Gate replica) but the favourite for me was to walk up through the old fort Pasir Panjang brick wall entrance on a wide easy road to the 6in gun and other battery positions. The gun was originally installed around the 1890s (found I think in 2001), but this whole section was of course a key position for WW2. This was the most reflective part of the walk for me, and here you are sheltered in the trees. Strolling around I took about 90 mins. There were not many folks walking here, almost as many fishing on the front.

REVIEW_TITLE: Forest and sea in one place
REVIEW_BODY: If you don't mind the long boring walk from the MRT station you will find a nice forest and seaside walk at the end. The place is a bit underdeveloped lacking some food stalls, cold drink and ice cream vendors at the sea side as well as an electric cart service zipping visitors between the MRT station and the sea side. The sea view is nice and if you venture to the end of the pier you can see Keppel's post-apocalyptic architecture, harbor front and Fort Siloso on Sentosa island.

Historical place by the sea. You can see the port from the park along the coast. People are fishing. This place is enjoyed by many locals. BBQ pits, dogs, roller bladers. You name it. Beautiful sunset too. Bring bug spray.

REVIEW_TITLE: Not a very special park but close to the sea
REVIEW_BODY: The park itself is not very special and quite small. There is also an exhibition of WWII items scattered through the whole park. But the best part is the closeness to the sea. Wonderful to sit there in the evening and see the sunset, with the harbor and a lot of ships in front of it (admittedly, not what you would expect from a "sunset at the sea")

Another of Singapore's beautiful nature reserves. My only complaint was not noticing the signboard map when exiting Labrador Park MRT station. My fault, look for the full map right at the top of the escalator exit. Without the map, it is a bit confusing to find the access road to the Reserve, I had to ask for help. From the MRT, it is a 10 minute or so walk.

I didn't know to expect the military history. Pillboxes still in situ and battery guns along with children's playgrounds. This really brought Singapore's past to life for me. There are paths along the beach, but also through the forest along the ridge.

It is possible to make a circuit through the Nature Reserve and return to the MRT by backtracking the same road as when arriving. But, I choose to follow the path along Berlayer Creek, a wise choice, I think. This is a mangrove area with very interesting wildlife. This trail also returns you to the Labrador Park MRT. You can also walk along the Bukit Chermin Boardwalk by Keppel Bay and view the yachts and condominiums.

Nestled across the narrow channel from Sentosa, this nature reserve is quiet and well-kept. There's a paved path and some stairs in different areas. Still stroller accessible though. It can be a hot walk if coming out during the day though. There are numerous areas to gaze out at the sea and the port and the pathway eventually links up with a small waterfront area. Parking is available on site. Washrooms are available near the top of the hill as well.

It's a nice area for stroll and history buffs will especially enjoy it as there are numerous batteries/sites from World War II. The Singapore Walks Battle of Singapore tour stops here and you're treated to walking tour of the hilltop and batteries. As others have stated, it makes for a nice stroll by the sea.

REVIEW_TITLE: Good for residents, but don't go out of your way
REVIEW_BODY:
Little tricky to find if walking from MRT.
Small area- the walk from MRT was about the same length as walk thru park.
No hard-copy of maps available.
Get a view a bottom of the ocean plus ocean liners and ship yards in the distance.
Some mosquito's.
Walking paths and roads are clean.
Felt safe going solo.

There are some remains bring you back to WWII period of Singapore. Read the information board to understand the battle between Britain & Japan here. From the park, you can walk along the walkway to Kepple Bay & Harbourfront. The view is worth to see.

- Quiet park, great for walks and cycling.
- Conservation area for mangrove ecosystem
- WW2-ea defence structures (a cannon, bunker and parts of the old fort) still exist.
- Guided tour (paid) of bunker is available.
- Dining option: Tamarind Hill (scenic, exquisite), or Seah Im Food Centre opp. Harbourfront.
- Possible to access Keppel Island (private yacht dock, marina, entertainment)
- Near MRT sations and many public busses.

First time here with friends and Furkids. Had a great time here as we walked by the sea.

Lots of shady areas to either rest or enjoy a picnic. BBQ pits are available too. Best part was the Super lovely Breeze that accompanied us throughout the afternoon making the outing such a great one.

Visit the historic Labrador jetty at one end and the Dragon Tooth Gate at the other. There’s also a children’s playground. A great place for families. And to make it even more fun, there’s no entrance fees too.
A nice place for an afternoon/ evening walk by the sea , visit the old gun embankments that protected the harbour very picturesque..

REVIEW_TITLE: Fascinating war relic sites amidst rich biodiversity
REVIEW_BODY: If one is going by car, they can directly proceed to the parking lot’s depending on the area they want to visit. Alternatively if by MRT/BUS one has to walk for some distance before entering the main park. The initial part has some fascinating war relics and sites amidst rich biodiversity. A jogging track goes around the reserve offering a scenic route for those looking to work out. It is one of the parks connected via a nine-kilometre stretch of inter-connected open spaces. It can take you to port areas with private yachts with beautiful surroundings and clean water. Overall a nice place for outing with friends or family alike.

REVIEW_TITLE: Enjoy the walking, jogging, picnic and watching the sunset
REVIEW_BODY: Exit labrador park mrt (yellow line) and turn right where you will see the walkway with mangroves. The walk way is a very relaxing area where trees covers the sunlight and can hear the birds plus cricket sound. You will see the sea at the end of the walk way - on your right is the path to the picnic area while left side leads to the bridge. You can have a picnic there underneath the trees overlooking the sea and sentosa. You can also have some bbq there as well. There are toilets, vending machines, picnic tables and chairs, playground and fishing area. We were able to see the beautiful sunset facing the harbour.
Great place to hang out during weekends, you can do short jungle trek with sigh seeing or walk around seafront. Bbq pits are avaliable through nparks website.

It was a pleasant morning walk this time for a change of location. Took us about 10,000 steps to complete a round circuit. Along the way, one can view unique Condo architecture landscape , yachts, ships, our ports and a peacock (a pleasant surprise) to it round up our walk. For tourists who wants to try it, you could take MRT - via Circle Line (Yellow Colour) and drop off at Labrador Station. There will be sign directions to guide you.
A place that’s filled with many types of natural plants. Even monkeys, squirrels and monitor lizards is sighted in it. The water is so clear that we can see the bottom of the stream.
Such a good place to rilex... feelimg vold at there and windy... can do barbeque with friends or cycling and walking around. From mrt walking about 30 minutes.

REVIEW_TITLE: Picture spots with nature and history and a six inch gun
REVIEW_BODY:
Colleagues brought me here to scout a filming location, and this was a hot favorite in our list. The Labrador Jetty is a picture-perfect spot if you get the subjects on the jetty and your camera on the park side to take a shot against the shipping docks behind the jetty.

Another draw is the Pasir Panjang Battery and the remains of the fortress that once operated on this spot. It's quite a walk to get to these locations, so I had to give those a miss. However, the 'six inch gun' was near the car park and we could have had a peek if it was not about to rain.

There is some fauna in the area as well, as I ran across some local jungle fowl and a peacock.
Here is why you can see the big guns of singapore which were suppose to make Singapore a fortress back in history.

REVIEW_TITLE: Nice quiet park with view of Singapore refineries and busy cargo port
REVIEW_BODY: This park is not well known to tourists or even locals unless you live or work around this area. Nearest MRT is Labrador but the park itself is quite a long walk from the station (it's about 8 mins drive, estimate 30 mins walk). The scenery is boring while walking there but when you reached the park, you will be greeted with the view of Singapore oil refineries and also cargo port in the distance. I went there in the evening and was rewarded with a beautiful sunset view. There's a nice walkway along the waters and a World War II artillery. There's also a jetty and a playground. There are many parks in Singapore to explore so would not recommend this park unless you are somewhere nearby.

REVIEW_TITLE: One of the best sunset view
REVIEW_BODY: One of the best sunset view to watch from this park. Nice to walk or jogging but it is not appropriate during the raining time. Family outing with BBQ section can be in here too.

Labrador Nature Reserve is part of a 10 km chain of interconnecting parks, forests and green belts along the top of Singapore's Southen Ridges.

Along the walk there are magnificent views across the sea and if look closely you may find some World War Two tunnels dug by the British defenders against the invading Japanese.

REVIEW_TITLE: Labrador Park/ Marina Keppel Bridge/Harbour Front
REVIEW_BODY: Jacqi (UK) n me decided to spend a day exploring Labrador Nature Reserve and take a long evening walk on the trail that leads to Marina Keppel Bridge and ending at Harbour Front for our meal and shopping including Vivo city ,all in ,at the World Trade Center. Look at the picture and you will know how beautiful n refreshing the evening must be! Romantic tooif you are with your sweet
Accesible via Labrador MRT station, 10-15mins walk to the walk. Unique nature walk which is educational, history found in nature.

REVIEW_TITLE: Day trip with UK friend Jacqi
REVIEW_BODY: Alight at Labrador MRT and took a walk into the Nature Park & down to the beach front and walk towards the broad walk that leads to Marina at Keppel Bridge to view the sunset at the marina area. Dont miss this beautiful scenic walk which will link you to Habour Front and Vivo City or Sentosa if you like.
